justification: “Neuroimaging studies using action-based video games in the scanner have consequently reported activation in large portions of the cortex, including brain regions involved in top-down attentional processes (Anderson et al. 2011).”
The same sentence notes that video-game fMRI studies showed cortical activation related to “goal oriented behaviour (Bavelier et al. 2012).”
Within the list of findings from video-game fMRI research, the authors include “spatial (Anderson et al. 2011)” processing as one of the cognitive functions revealed by brain activation patterns.
The review states that fMRI studies have reported activation linked to “information (Anderson et al. 2016) processing” during game play.
The authors cite evidence that fMRI data during video-game tasks has captured neural signatures of “skill acquisition (Erickson et al. 2010).”
They also mention that fMRI studies have examined neural activity related to “reward performance (Koepp et al. 1998)” while participants played video games.
